message:
Top Internet and Browser vendors are working on a draft for HTTP2: a new version of the protocol at the foundation of the Internet.
Daniel Stenberg (author and maintainer of cURL, who works for Mozilla) shares some of the details about the process and current state of draft.
Things I learned:
- HTTP2 will be binary, not text based.
- HTTP2 started with Google's SPDY protocol.
- You can enable HTTP2 today if you're using Firefox (I turned it on in Nightly). I think Twitter already supports HTTP2 (but I'm not sure).
- So far, HTTP2 will allow for non-SSL connection. There's a push to make SSL/TLS required for all connection (which I'm in a favor of, I have to say).
- Main goal seems to be to reduce number of trips between server and client.
He put together a PDF with all the details. Check it out. It's not all technical details but also history of HTTP and how we got here.
http://daniel.haxx.se/http2/

data.message: HTTP in Binary, they should at least change the name :)

From the document, page 14:
"http2 is a binary protocol.
Let that sink in for a minute. If you're a person that's been involved in internet protocols before, chances are that you react strongly with instinct against this and prepare your refute arguments to spell out how useful it is with protocols that are made with text/ascii and that you've done HTTP 1.1 requests numerous times by telnetting to servers and
entered the requests by hand.
http2 is binary to make the framing much easier. Figuring out the start and the end of frames is one of the really complicated things in HTTP 1.1 and actually in text based protocols in general. By moving away from optional white spaces and different ways to write the same thing, implementations become simpler.
Also, it makes it much easier to separate the actual protocol parts from the framing -which in HTTP1 is confusingly intermixed."

To be honest, I'm not sure what effect it has to make HTTP binary. Won't I still be able to see the content sent and received?
What are the side effects?
You guys know that the Text in HTTP refers to the documents not that it's made of text; Hyper Text rather than regular Text. Right?
Yes of course especially one of its needs is to serves html files :D

Text formats are much easier to debug, but they are less efficient than binary formats. To add features like gzip compression & SSL, they had to convert binary data to be text compatible using base64, which adds almost a 20% overhead.
